description: Borrowed from Latin excursio (“a running out, an inroad, invasion, a setting out, beginning of a speech”), from excurrere (“to run out”), from ex (“out”) + currere (“to run”).

entries.meaning: A brief recreational trip; a journey out of the usual way.
examples: While driving home I took an excursion and saw some deer.

entries.meaning: A wandering from the main subject: a digression.
(aviation) An occurrence where an aircraft runs off the end or side of a runway or taxiway, usually during takeoff, landing, or taxi.
(phonetics) A deviation in pitch, for example in the syllables of enthusiastic speech.

verbs.description: excursion (third-person singular simple present excursions, present participle excursioning, simple past and past participle excursioned)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To go on a recreational trip or excursion.
examples: Yesterday I excursioned twenty miles; to-day I write a few letters.
